ref: 13085 sájati ʻ is attached, embraces ʼ Dhātup. (ásakta aor. ʻ adhered to ʼ TBr., āˊsajāmi ʻ place in ʼ RV.). 2. *sājayati. 3. sañjayati ʻ attaches to ʼ Bhag., ʻ couples ʼ Mn. 4. sajyátē (sajjatē MBh.) intr. ʻ hangs on ʼ ŚBr., ʻ is occupied with ʼ MBh. 5. saktá -- ʻ clinging to ʼ AV. [Kaf. Dard. K. and WPah. presuppose MIA. *ṣā̆(y) -- , *ṣajj -- (*ṣacc -- ), *ṣatta -- . These may derive from √sañj with ṣ -- replacing s -- in the simplex after cmpds. with ati (AV.), vyati (TBr.), anu (ŚBr.), abhi (MBh.), ni (RV.), pari (MBh.), prati, vi (TS.), adhivi (MBh.), abhivi (BhP.). Dhp. has &gacute -- ~ saṅgá -- Brough Dhp 101. Cf. similar replacement of dental by retroflex in √sthā, √stambh. T. Burrow's (BSOAS xii 650) assumption of a √*sraj ~ √*sañj is unlikely and unnecessary. All NIA. words under 1 and 2 (except Kho. šoyek in which š -- can derive only from ś -- or ṣ -- , since śr -- is preserved) phonet. and semant. equally well (1) < śráyati in Si. sayanavā, (2) < śrāyayati (IIFL iii 3, 170, Buddruss Woṭ 125, Burrow KharDoc 14). But this would not account for their association with intr. or pass. stem *ṣajj -- or *ṣacc -- , and pp. and pret. *ṣatta -- . Possibly śráyati and *ṣajati coalesced in NIA. as a pres. st. for which only *ṣajj -- (replaced anal. by *ṣacc -- ) and *ṣatta -- served as pass. -- intr. and pp. Thus Paš.chil. ṣītik ʻ it has stuck ʼ may be *ṣia -- < śritá -- X *ṣatta -- . -- √sañj]

lang: Language of `Kharoṣṭhī Inscriptions discovered by Sir Aurel Stein in Chinese Turkestan' edited by A. M. Boyer, E. J. Rapson, and E. Senart
ref: NiDoc. ṣayati ʻ holds on to ʼ;

lang: Chilasi dialect of Shina or of Pashai
ref: chil. ṣ -- ʻ to stick to, cling to, be attached to ʼ;
Kho. (Lor.) šoyek ʻ to come near, approach ʼ;
Phal. ṣūm ʻ I put on (clothes) ʼ;
Sh. ṣóĭki̯ (1 sg. ṣa̯m, 2 imper. ṣe) ʻ to fix, apply, attack, hit (with a missile) ʼ; --
Wg. ṣä ʻ for, to ʼ absol. of a pres. st. *ṣa -- (cf.
